text:
*IDEA:* a native hubl function to get a list of all pages by `id`, `internal_title`, and `slug` with a filter for `is_draft`, `published`, and `content_staging_version` and another filter for `domain`

something like ```{{ cms_get_pages( id, is_draft, domain ) }}```
There is this function here: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/en/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-functions#page-by-id> but i think expanding on that one would be awesome
My idea is something that i would love to see integrated into the compile process for css in  HubSpot.... Autoprefixer .. please. This would be an amazing addon.

If this gets added - I would really like the ability to set the filter.

I have to build a lot of sites for older browsers and this would really help.

That said not to be negative, autoprefixer is going to eventually completely go away in about -3 years
With SCSS too please
please please please please
Yeah! like maybe ```pages_by_domain( domain, <true or false for is_draft> )```
i am ready to contribute in the development part :raised_hand_with_fingers_splayed::skin-tone-3::raised_hand_with_fingers_splayed::skin-tone-3:

> That said not to be negative, autoprefixer is going to eventually completely go away in about -3 years

Wait what's this

Well autoprefixer exists to solve a problem that won’t exist in about 3 years.

browser prefixes are going away completely. all of the modern browsers do not need the existing prefixes, new ones are not being created, and IE will be phased out
Oh

basically w3c and the browser vendors kinda came to an agreement that using prefixes has negative consequences on the web, because they were never meant to be used for production sites.

They were a way of testing the new features before they were ready.

Browsers are moving to using flags in browsers for enabling/disabling features.

If a browser doesn’t support a feature it fails @supports

allowing us to do what we’ve always done(provide fallbacks for browsers that don’t support the features we want) while simultaneously reducing the number of bugs that the prefixed versions of features introduced.

add :sprocket: menu to html email previews, primarily so we can grab the developer info. Or if you want the code to be true to the real email you could instead just put the dev info link in the template editor or email editor somewhere
But that doesnt solve for older browsers that still need to be supported.
Not every client uses the newest stuff.
what I’m saying is 3 years from now IE will be dead
on new stuff yes you are right.
i dont think it will be as used.
but in web years 3 years is like 20 human years :wink:

once IE is dead, it autoprefixer’s use will drop off like a cliff. because webkit prefixes are already largely unnecessary, the only ones that are necessary right now are special ones for pseudo elements.
those too are going away
i use it for flexbox and grid.
which i use heavily now.
yes but again both of those things you wont need prefixes for
as well as gradients, ect
Edge, Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Safari all auto update. and are dropping support for prefixes completely. with special pseudo elements being last to go
same goes for gradients
i understand. but i am just referencing the edge cases where they are stuck using older stuff.
<-- this is coming from the guy who routinely has to build sites for clients stuck on IE 9
same here
you wont be stuck using prefixes for things like gradients. they’re already supported natively in all of those browsers. and like I said IE is going to completely die
in-fact actually gradient css appears to actually be fully supported in IE 10+ the prefixes fix support for IE 8 and 9, and some old versions of safari with low usage

form the form tag, there should be a parameter that would look for a JS function for onLoad because its really annoying to not be able to do anything to the form with JS without having to use the embed (or a settimeout) /rant
